children.text: Use counting to determine how many (to at least 30).
Implement correct procedures by matching one object to one object (one-to-one correspondence).

Implement correct counting procedures by pointing to one object at a time (one-to-one tagging) using one counting word for every object (synchrony), while keeping track of objects that have and have not been counted.
Recognize that the last number tells the quantity of the set (cardinality).
Recognize zero as the count of "no objects".
Use the 0-9 sequence in a fixed order when counting to recall the forward number sequence to at least 30 and the backward number sequence from 10.
Understand that there are relationships between and among numbers (to at least 10).
Recognize that the number said when the last object of a set is counted includes all of the objects previously counted (inclusion).
Compare sets of objects and numbers using appropriate vocabulary (more, less, same/equal, one more, one less, first, second, third, etc.).
Recognize sets of objects in common patterned arrangements (0-6) to tell how many without counting (subitizing).
Explain numbers (0-10) in relationship to benchmark numbers 5 and 10.
Explain how subsets relate to the set as a whole (part-part-whole).
Use numerals to represent physical models and representations.
Use estimation to determine if a set of objects is "more than 10," "less than 10," or "about the same as ten."
Understand the concepts of joining and separating through modeling (to at least 10).
Use informal language (and, minus/subtract, the same as) to describe the joining situations (putting together) and separating situations (breaking apart).
Use fair shares (equipartition) to solve story problems.
Share fairly (equipartition) collections of up to 10 items between 2 or 4 people, and reassemble.
Represent the whole numbers from 0 through 100 by counting, reading, writing and the use of physical models.
Understand the sequential order of the counting numbers and their relative magnitudes.
Use a range of numbers (1-10, 11-20, 21-30, etc.) to estimate the quantity of a given set.
Understand that counting by 2s, 5s and 10s is counting groups of items by that amount.
Recognize patterns in written numerals and use those patterns to determine the order of numbers including the number before and after, 1 more and 1 less and 2 more and 2 less.
Understand that the order of the digits determines the given number and use this understanding to compare sets and numbers.
Illustrate whole numbers to 30 in groups of tens and ones using objects, pictures and numbers.
Use strategies to compose and decompose numbers 0-100.
Use part-part-whole relationships (including 2 or more parts), benchmark numbers 5 and 10, doubles and near doubles to compose and decompose numbers.
Understand the concept of ten–and-some-more with numbers 11-20.
Understand 10 more and 10 less from any given number to 100.
Use efficient strategies to solve a variety of story problems and generate a justification for the reasonableness of the answer.
Use fluent recall of addition facts (sums to 10) and the related subtraction facts to solve problems.
Use strategies to solve single and multi-step addition and subtraction story problems to 30.
Use strategies to solve single-step addition and subtraction story problems to 100.
Understand sharing fairly (equipartitioning) with collections of discrete items and single continuous wholes.
Understand that a region or set must be divided into equal parts of the whole and when reassembled recreates the whole.
Understand the concept of "left-over" (remainder).
Understand that even numbers are sets that can be shared fairly between two people and odd sets cannot.
Represent whole numbers from 0 through 1,000 in terms of the base ten numeration system.
Illustrate whole numbers to 1,000 in groups of ones, tens, hundreds and thousands by composing and decomposing flexible groups.
Interpret the value of a digit (1-9 and 0) in a multi-digit numeral by its position within the number with models, words and numerals.
Use benchmark numbers (25, 50, 75, 100, 200, etc.) to determine a reasonable estimate.
Understand counting by 10's and 100's on and off the decade.
Compare whole numbers less than 1,000 with symbols (<, >) and words.
Use multiple strategies fluently to solve story problems involving addition and subtraction.
Remember addition and related subtraction facts (sums to 20) to develop fluency.
Use properties of addition to solve multi-step, two-digit story problems.
Use benchmark numbers to facilitate mental math strategies, estimation and judging reasonableness of answers.
Apply strategies to compose and decompose when adding and subtracting whole numbers less than 300.
Understand the concept of division as fair shares (equipartitioning).
Illustrate division by making equal sized groups using models.
Interpret verbally the share as "1/nth of the whole" and the whole as "n times as much" as the share.
Understand the relationship between the size of a fair share (of a set or of a single continuous whole) and the number of people sharing (compensatory principle).
Understand the numerical value of whole numbers 0 to 10,000.
Represent whole numbers using models, words, numbers (symbolic) and expanded form by composing and decomposing.
Compare whole numbers less than 10,000 with symbols (<, >) and words.
Illustrate composing a higher-value number by multiplying by 10 and composing a lower-value number by dividing by 10.
Use strategies to solve multi-digit addition and subtraction problems.
Use multiple strategies to solve multi-digit, single-step and multi-step addition and subtraction problems.
Use estimation to determine the reasonableness of solutions
Understand multiplication and division and their relationship using facts 0-10.
Illustrate the meaning of multiplication and division using multiple models.
Use estimation, properties and efficient strategies to solve single step multiplication and division problems.
Understand the meaning of fractions as sharing equally (equipartitioning) using models.
Illustrate equal parts (equipartitioning) with situations involving numbers less than one and mixed numbers greater than one.
Represent fractions or mixed numbers using symbolic notation (a/b).
Represent equivalent fractions with models by composing and decomposing fractions into equivalent fractions (using related fractions: halves, fourths, eighths; thirds, sixths).
Compare a given fraction to benchmark numbers of 0, ½, 1, using a variety of strategies.
Represent a fair share of a collection of discrete items as the amount per person (the unit ratio or n:1).
Understand the value of whole numbers and decimal representations from 0.01 to 100,000.
Represent whole numbers and decimals using models, words and numbers (symbolic).
Compare sets of two to six numbers, arranging them from least to greatest or greatest to least.
Illustrate the place value structure of decimals and whole numbers when multiplying and dividing by 10.
Use strategies to solve problems involving multi-digit addition, subtraction, multiplication and division of whole numbers.
Use strategies to develop fluency in solving problems using up to four-digit addition and subtraction (larger number with calculator).
Use strategies to develop fluency for multiplication with two-digit by one-digit and two-digit by two-digit numbers.
Use strategies with three-digit by one-digit division with and without remainders to develop fluency.
Use estimation of whole number operations in meaningful contexts to justify the reasonableness of the solution.
Use area models to understand multiplication and related concepts such as factors, multiples (including squares), prime and composite numbers.
Understand the concept of equivalence with models as it applies to fractions, improper fractions, mixed numbers and decimals.
Identify equivalent fractions (using halves, fourths, eights; thirds, sixths, twelfths and fifths, tenths, hundredths)
Compare fractions, decimals and mixed numbers using models, benchmarks (e.g. 0, ½, 0.5, 1, n/n, 1 ½, 1.5, 2, 2n/n…) and reasoning.
Represent mixed numbers as improper fractions and improper fractions as mixed numbers.
Understand the equivalence of fractions as related to the size of the whole.
Represent pairs of equivalent ratios by composing and decomposing to include the smallest equivalent whole number ratio (ratio unit).
Use models to represent addition and subtraction of fractions and decimals.
Illustrate addition and subtraction of fractions, with like denominators, using area and length models.
Illustrate addition and subtraction of decimals using area and length models.
Use estimation to justify the reasonableness of solutions.
Understand the value of whole numbers, fractions and decimal representations from 0.001 to 1,000,000.
Understand the value of whole numbers to 1,000,000.
Compare fractions of like denominators symbolically and unlike denominators using area models and number lines (<, >, ≤, ≥, =, ≠).
Represent the relationship among fractions (halves, fourths, fifths and tenths) and decimals.
Represent fair share of multiple discrete wholes and continuous wholes symbolically and name an individual share as a/b.
Use combinations of whole number addition, subtraction, multiplication and division to solve multi-step problems in context.
Use strategies to develop fluency in whole number addition and subtraction to solve multi-step problems in context.
Use multiplication up to three-digit by two-digit and division up to three-digit by two-digit with and without remainders to develop fluency.
Use the concept of division to solve problems with remainders expressed as numbers left over and as fractions.
Identify prime factors (for numbers less than 60) and multiples by composing and decomposing whole numbers.
Use estimation to justify the reasonableness of solutions.
Use strategies to solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions and decimals.
Use a variety of strategies to solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions with unlike denominators.
Use a variety of strategies to solve problems involving addition and subtraction of decimals.
Use estimation of sums and differences of fractions and decimals to justify reasonableness of solutions.
Use tables and graphs to compare ratios.
Represent two quantities that vary by the same factor (proportionately) using a ratio table.
Use graphing of two-column tables to compare ratio values.
Use a variety of strategies (including models, pictures, mental computation) to solve problems involving multiplication and division of non-negative rational numbers.
Apply multiplication and division to non-negative decimal numbers.
Apply multiplication and division to non-negative fractions.
Use combinations of addition, subtraction, multiplication and division for non-negative rational numbers to solve multi-step problems.
Use formal algorithms for all four operations for non-negative rational numbers.
Understand when the associative and commutative properties hold true for non-negative rational numbers.
Understand the relationship between integers, non-negative decimals, fractions and percents.
Compare integers and non-negative decimals, fractions and percents using the number line.
Represent percents as decimals and fractions; fractions as decimals and percents; and decimals as fractions and percents.
Use the concept of unit rate to solve problems.
Use ratio tables or graphs to represent unit rates.
Use unit rates to solve problems.
Understand large and small numbers using exponents and exponential notation.
Represent numbers using scientific notation.
Represent numbers as prime factors with exponents.
Compare numeric expressions using repeated multiplication and exponential notation.
Use proportional reasoning to find missing values in problems.
Use proportional reasoning to find missing values for part-to-part ratio and part-to-whole ratio problems.
Use given conversion factors to convert measures given in either customary or metric units to the other system.
Use sampling strategies to collect data about unknown populations.
Apply an understanding of percent and percent change to estimate and solve problems, including percents greater than 100.
Use concepts of percent to solve problems.
Use concepts of percent of change to solve problems.
Use all four arithmetic operations to solve problems involving integers.
Use addition and subtraction of integers to solve problems.
Use multiplication and division of integers to solve problems.
Apply combinations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division to solve multi-step problems with all rational numbers.
Use all four operations for all rational numbers, including formal algorithms.
Understand the structure of the Real number system.
Classify Real numbers as natural, whole, integer, rational or irrational providing a justification.
Represent Real numbers on a number line using opposites and absolute value.
Compare Real numbers.
Understand the concepts of equality.
Recognize that any given group of objects (up to 10) can be separated into sub groups in multiple ways that are equivalent in number to the original group.
Explain equivalent relationships using words (and, minus/subtract, the same as), numbers and objects, rather than symbols (+, -, =).
Understand the meaning of repeating patterns.
Represent repeating patterns using actions, words or objects.
Use repeating patterns to make predictions and extend simple repeating patterns.
Use relationships between addition and subtraction to solve problems.
Use models to demonstrate addition properties (commutative, associative and identity).
Use models to demonstrate the inverse relationship between addition and subtraction.
Apply the concept of equality.
Use the equal sign to show the relationship between one side of the equation and the other.
Interpret simple number sentences as models and models as number sentences in order to solve.
Analyze repeating patterns.
Analyze patterns to identify the unit, correct errors and extend the patterns.
Translate patterns into symbolic representations using actions, words and models.
Classify numbers into the categories of odd and even.
Recognize patterns created with odd and even numbers.
Represent situations found in story problems as number sentences with unknowns.
Understand how a verbal situation is translated into an equation.
Understand how a variable represents an unknown.
Use patterns to solve problems.
Understand that patterns grow or repeat.
Apply patterns to properties of numbers and operations.
Illustrate the associative, commutative and the identity properties of multiplication.
Represent properties of multiplication with models, including arrays, and equations.
Use the concept of equality with unknown quantities.
Use the concept of equality to solve problems with unknown quantities.
Analyze numeric and non-numeric patterns.
Indentify the type of pattern in numeric and non-numeric patterns.
Predict missing terms in patterns.
Understand patterns to translate it into new forms.
Use mathematical properties to examine numerical relationships and solve mathematical problems.
Use mathematical properties (associative, commutative, distributive and identity) to make conjectures about observed relationships and to solve problems.
Use models to write equations and inequalities with variables.
Use models to write multi-step equations.
Use models to write one-step inequalities with variables.
Use order of operations.
Analyze patterns to identify rules.
Use rules to describe numeric growing patterns (arithmetic sequences) and describe numeric growing patterns using rules.
Use rules to describe non-numeric growing patterns and illustrate non-numeric growing patterns using rules.
Use rules to find missing values in numeric and non-numeric patterns.
Apply mathematical operations to solve equations.
Represent situations as algebraic equations.
Use combinations of addition, subtraction, multiplication and division with whole numbers to solve one- and two- step equations.
Use addition and subtraction of decimals and fractions with variables to solve one-step equations.
Apply the concept of inequality.
Represent problem situations with inequalities.
Identify values of a variable as a solution for an inequality.
Analyze growing and repeating patterns to solve problems.
Use numbers, pictures, tables, graphs and algebraic expressions to represent numeric and non-numeric patterns to solve problems.
Analyze an arithmetic sequence to generate a rule and generate a rule using an arithmetic sequence to solve problems.
Apply mathematical operations and properties for non-negative rational numbers to solve one-step equations and inequalities.
Use verbal descriptions and algebraic equations and inequalities to represent problem situations.
Use mathematical operations and properties to solve one-step equations.
Use mathematical operations and properties to solve inequalities.

Analyze patterns to determine the rule that enables accurate predictions of missing numbers, including the n<sup>th</sup> term, of arithmetic sequences (x<sub>1</sub>, x<sub>2</sub>, x<sub>3</sub>, x<sub>n</sub>).
Analyze patterns of arithmetic sequences to determine the rule that defines the pattern.
Use the rule to predict the n<sup>th</sup> term of an arithmetic sequence.
Use a given rule to determine the pattern.
Analyze the data presented in qualitative graphs in terms of position, time, change and rate of change.
Represent the essential elements of a scenario in graphical form.
Analyze the data presented in a qualitative graph to solve problems or answer questions.

Apply mathematical operations and properties for integers and non-negative fractions and decimals to solve two-step equations and inequalities with integer or non-negative fraction and decimal solutions.
Use mathematical operations and properties to solve equations.
Use mathematical operations and properties to solve inequalities.
Represent change in the relationship between two variables in arithmetic sequences.
Represent relationships between two variables in an arithmetic sequence using tables, graphs and algebraic equations.
Explain how a change in the relationship between two variables affects the table, graph and equation.
Understand the rate of change to solve problems.
Represent the rate of change in a set of data from an arithmetic sequence using tables, graphs and algebraic equations.
Interpret the meaning of the rate of change.
Use the combining of like terms and the distributive property to write equivalent expressions.
Use area models to illustrate the distributive property.
Use Greatest Common Factor and area models to determine possible dimensions of a rectangle when given the area.
Use like terms to write equivalent expressions.
Use a given value of the variable to identify equivalent expressions.
Apply mathematical operations and properties to solve inequalities and equations, including variables on both sides.
Use mathematical operations and properties to solve equations.
Use mathematical operations and properties to solve inequalities.
Understand the use of linear relationships in slope-intercept form to solve relevant problems.
Translate a linear relationship between its verbal, tabular, graphic and algebraic forms.
Interpret the meaning of x-intercepts and y-intercepts.
Represent a linear equation in slope-intercept form, given the slope and y-intercept, slope and a point or two points.
Classify ordered pairs as correct or incorrect solutions to a linear equation.
Interpret the meaning and value of slope of linear relationships.
Represent slope given a table, graph, linear equation or two points.
Compare the slopes of two linear relationships to determine whether the lines are parallel or intersect at a point.
Interpret the rate of change in tables to identify linear and non-linear relationships between variables.
Use the Cartesian coordinate system to solve problems involving a linear inequality.
Represent a linear inequality on the Cartesian coordinate system.
Use graphs to find solutions to a linear inequality.
Classify two-dimensional figures as circles, rectangles (including squares) and triangles and three-dimensional shapes as spheres, cubes, cylinders and cones.
Use geometric properties (open, closed, sides and angles) to identify and compare two-dimensional and three-dimensional figures.
Construct a design or figure using its parts.
Recognize parts of figures to identify sides and angles of 2-D figures.
Use spatial reasoning to solve problems.
Use positional and directional terms to describe locations and movement of objects.
Use spatial reasoning to move objects to fill shapes.
Use spatial reasoning to model objects in the environment.
Classify two-dimensional figures (polygons) as parallelogram, rhombus, trapezoid and hexagon and three-dimensional figures (polyhedra) as prism and pyramid according to geometric attributes.
Describe the attributes of the figures, such as: number of faces or edges, equal sizes of sides and numbers of angles.
Use the attributes of figures to recognize different variations of figures.
Compare geometric figures in terms of their perspectives and orientations.
Summarize relationships of objects using proximity, position, perspective, orientation and navigation.
Compare different perspectives and orientations by composing and decomposing geometric figures.
Classify the faces of polyhedra as polygons.
Classify angles as greater than, equal to or less than a right angle.
Recognize faces of polyhedra (cube, triangular prism, rectangular prism, triangular pyramid, and rectangular/square pyramid) as polygons (triangles and rectangles, including squares).
Compare polygons to determine whether they are or are not congruent.
Classify polygons in three ways; same size, same shape (congruent); same size, different shape; and different size, same shape.
Understand congruence in polygons with different orientations (proximity, position, directions and turns).
Classify figures according to their properties.
Classify two-dimensional figures according to their properties to develop definitions of classes of shapes such as quadrilaterals.
Classify three-dimensional figures according to their properties to develop definitions of classes of shapes such as pyramids.
Represent points, paths, lines and geometric figures on a rectangular coordinate grid.
Represent points with whole number and letter coordinates on a rectangular coordinate grid.
Infer possible paths along the grid between given points on a rectangular coordinate grid.
Represent geometric figures with vertices at points on a coordinate grid.
Identify parallel and perpendicular lines on a rectangular coordinate grid.
Understand the concept of symmetry and transformations.
Understand the concept of symmetry (line, rotational, both, neither).
Understand the concepts of transformations including reflections, translations and rotations.
Use symmetry to understand relationships to transformations as they apply to two-dimensional shapes.
Apply properties to classify polygons.
Classify triangles and quadrilaterals based on angles, sides, diagonals and shape (convex and concave quadrilaterals).
Use triangles to categorize polygons by the sums of the measures of interior angles.
Understand the relationships between rectangles and rectangular prisms.
Compare the dimensions of a rectangular prism to its two-dimensional net.
Compare the area of a two-dimensional net to the surface area of its three-dimensional rectangular prism.
Represent one- and two-dimensional geometric figures in the Cartesian coordinate system.
Identify the origin, axes, quadrants and coordinates on the Cartesian coordinate system.
Describe the intersection of two or more geometric figures in the Cartesian coordinate system (e.g. intersection of a circle and a line).
Summarize the effect of translations.
Summarize the effect of reflections across horizontal and vertical lines.
Understand similar and congruent figures.
Understand the role of proportionality and corresponding angles in similar figures.
Summarize the properties of congruent and similar figures.
Represent three-dimensional shapes using multiple perspectives.
Analyze three-dimensional shapes from a variety of two-dimensional perspectives.
Understand square roots and cube roots.
Understand the relationship between geometric squares, perfect squares and their square roots.
Understand the relationship between geometric cubes, cube numbers and their cube roots.
Infer an approximate square root of non-perfect squares between two consecutive integers.
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse to solve relevant problems.
Apply the concepts of squares and square roots with the Pythagorean Theorem to find the side lengths of right triangles.
Use the converse of the Pythagorean theorem to identify right triangles.
Apply properties of angle relationships to solve problems.
Use properties of adjacent, vertical, supplementary and complementary angles to solve problems.
Use properties of parallel lines cut by a transversal to determine angle measures.
Use proportional reasoning to determine arc lengths and central angles.
Understand rotations of points and two-dimensional geometric shapes about the origin in the Cartesian coordinate system.
Illustrate symbolic representation for rotations of points for 90°, 180°, 270°, both clockwise and counterclockwise about the origin.
Illustrate symbolic representation for rotations of two-dimensional geometric shapes for 90°, 180°, 270°, both clockwise and counterclockwise about the origin.

Recognize that length and weight* are attributes and can be measured.
*More properly mass, but most commonly understood as weight at this grade band.
Compare two objects using direct comparison in terms of length and weight.
Use appropriate vocabulary to describe differences in length and weight (e.g. longer, shorter, taller, heavier and lighter).
Understand the concept of time as it relates to sequences and personal referents.
Use the words "day, morning, afternoon, night (evening), today, tomorrow and yesterday" to refer to personal activities and events.
Understand that certain tools (such as daily schedule, calendar, clock and timer) are used to keep track of time, personal activities and events.
Recognize that the days of the week, months of the year and seasons occur in a sequence that repeat.

Use nonstandard units to estimate and measure length or weight* of objects.
*More properly mass, but most commonly understood as weight at this grade band.
Compare objects in terms of appropriate non-standard units of measurement.
Use comparative vocabulary to describe the relationship among three to five objects with respect to length (longer, shorter), weight (heavier, lighter) or duration.
Use the names of the days of the weeks and the months of the year to describe special activities and events.
Remember in order the names of the days of the week and months of the year.
Recognize the difference in the amount of time between a day, week and month.

Understand the use of non-standard units in measurement of length, weight*, capacity and area.
*More properly mass, but most commonly understood as weight at this grade band.
Compare objects with respect to their lengths, weights or capacities using non-standard units.
Understand that larger units can be subdivided into equivalent units (partition).
Understand that the same unit can be repeated to determine the measure (iteration).
Understand the relationship between the size of a unit and the number of units needed (compensatory principal).
Understand the measuring of two-dimensional space (area) using non-standard units.
Understand how to tell time.
Use analog and digital clocks to tell time to the hour and half hour.
Understand a.m. and p.m.
Use strategies to count money collections.
Remember the names and values of coins (penny, nickel, dime and quarter).
Use multiple strategies to count collections of coins up to one dollar ($1).
Use the symbols $ and ¢ properly.

Use metric units to measure length, weight*, capacity, and temperature to solve problems.
*More properly mass, but most commonly understood as weight at this grade band.
Select the most appropriate metric unit and tool to measure selected attributes; length (mm, cm, dm, m, km), weight (g, kg), capacity (mL, L) and temperature (°C) measurements.
Apply the processes of measurement (partitioning, transitivity, iteration and compensatory principle) to length and capacity.
Use estimation to interpret the reasonableness of length (cm, dm, m, km), weight (g, kg), capacity (ml, L) and temperature (°C) measurements.
Understand how to determine area.
Use rectangles and composite rectangular shapes to find area.
Use clocks to tell time.
Use analog and digital clocks to tell time to the nearest 5 minutes.
Use various phrases to read time (quarter ‘til, noon, etc.).

Use customary units to measure length, weight*, capacity and temperature to solve problems.
*More properly mass, but most commonly understood as weight at this grade band.
Use the customary unit and appropriate tool to measure selected attributes.
Apply the processes of measurement (partitioning, transitivity, iteration and compensatory principle) to capacity and length.
Use estimation to interpret the reasonableness of length (inch, foot, yard and mile), weight (ounce and pound), capacity (ounces, cups, pints, quarts and gallons) and temperature (°F) measurements.
Understand the relationship between area and perimeter of polygons.
Understand the concept and how to determine the perimeter of composite rectangular figures.
Understand the relationship between area and perimeter of composite rectangular figures.
Use area models to illustrate multiplication of a unit fraction times a whole number.
Use a protractor to measure angles.
Understand the procedure for measuring angles to the nearest 5° with a protractor.

Use angle benchmarks to estimate and solve problems:
¼ turn, right angle, 90°,
½ turn, 180°,
¾ turn, 270°, and a
complete turn, 360°.
Use measurement of temperature and of elapsed time to solve problems.
Understand elapsed time to solve problems.
Understand negative and non-negative temperatures on a thermometer to solve problems.
Use the relationship between customary and metric measurements to estimate measures given in one system to its measure in the other system.
Use the relationships between customary and metric measurements to make estimates between systems.
Use attributes of polygons and formulas to determine perimeter and area.
Calculate the perimeter of polygons.
Calculate the area of polygons.
Use the approximate value of π to calculate the circumference and area of circles.
Compare the ratio of the circumference to the diameter to identify an approximate value of π.
Use formulas to determine the area and circumference of circles.
Use appropriate formulas and strategies to calculate the volume and surface area of cylinders and prisms.
Use strategies to calculate the volume of prisms and cylinders.
Use strategies to calculate the surface area of prisms and cylinders.
Apply scale factors to solve problems.
Use scale factors and proportional reasoning to solve problems involving indirect measurement and similar figures.
Use scale factors to solve problems with dilations of two-dimensional shapes from the origin.
Explain the effect of one or more changes in dimensions on perimeter, area, volume and surface area of two-dimensional and three-dimensional figures (prisms and cylinders).
Understand the effect that dimension changes have on perimeter and area of two-dimensional figures.
Understand the effect that dimension changes have on volume and surface area of prisms and cylinders.
Classify objects according to one attribute.
Use attribute vocabulary to describe how objects or groups of objects are alike and different.
Sort objects according to color, size, shape, texture and other age-appropriate attributes.
Understand that data can be collected, organized and displayed in a way that provides information about a question.
Use concrete objects or pictures to create cluster graphs and picture graphs to organize and represent data.
Analyze collected data to determine the answer to the question posed.
Infer the rule for classifying objects on the basis of two attributes.
Explain how a collection of objects with various attributes can be classified or sorted in different ways.
Use appropriate methods to collect, display, analyze and interpret statistical data in response to specific questions.
Represent data collected using picture graphs, line plots, lists and tallies to capture and represent categorical and numerical data.
Understand data from statistical investigations in order to develop and evaluate inferences and predictions.
Analyze parts of data and the set of data as a whole to determine what the data show in Venn diagrams (2 circle) and line plots.
Use counting concepts of grouping and comparing to illustrate the differences between values and frequencies in line plots.
Identify patterns and trends to make decisions using data.
Interpret data from statistical investigations.
Represent tables and bar graphs (with frequency intervals of 1, 2, 5 or 10).
Interpret data to identify shape (cluster, gap, and trend), center (typicality or mode) and range (variability) of the data set.
Explain results of simple probability experiments.
Understand the events of probability as being certain, likely, equally likely, unlikely, possible or impossible.
Explain the outcomes of simple probability experiments.
Interpret data from investigations involving one or two sets of data.
Interpret the data presented in circle graphs, relating the parts to the whole.
Represent collected data in line graphs.
Interpret one or two sets of data in terms of shape (cluster, gap, trend and unusual data points), center (typicality, mode or median) and range (variability) of the data set.
Understand the differences between individual-to-individual (ungrouped) comparisons and individual to group (grouped) comparisons.
Predict the outcomes of simple probability experiments.
Represent the possible outcomes (sample space) of simple probability experiments.
Represent probability and relative likelihood of events using fractions.
Interpret trends in data from statistical investigations.
Use data from statistical investigations presented in graphs to interpret trends.
Interpret appropriateness for specific questions by comparing multiple representations of one or more sets of data
Understand the relationships between experimental and theoretical probabilities for simple events.
Predict the outcomes of probability experiments for simple events based on theoretical probability.
Compare the outcomes from random experiments (experimental probability) to an expected outcome based on a theoretical probability.
Use strategies to identify sample spaces and probabilities.
Use tree diagrams and Fundamental Counting Principle to identify sample space and identify probabilities.
Use organized lists to display a sample space and identify probabilities.
Understand graphical displays of data in terms of shape, measures of center and variability.
Represent data using dot plots, stem and leaf plots and histograms.
Interpret distributions of data in terms of measures of center (mean, median and mode), shape (clusters, peaks and gaps) and variability (range).
Compare the meanings and uses of means, medians and modes.
Interpret information from a data set in terms of supporting or refuting statements about the data group.
Understand the relationships between experimental and the theoretical probabilities of compound, independent events for varying sample sizes.
Use the outcomes from random experiments to estimate a probability for compound, independent events.
Predict the outcomes of probability experiments for compound, independent events based on the theoretical probability.
Interpret the actual outcomes from probability experiments for compound, independent situations.
Compare the relationship between the experimental and theoretical probabilities of compound, independent events for varying sample sizes.
Interpret data using box plots.
Construct models of data using box plots.
Interpret distributions of data using quartiles, median, shape and interquartile range.
Infer conclusions that are consistent with available data.
Analyze graphical displays of two distributions of data in terms of their shape, measures of center and variability.
Summarize two sets of data using histograms, box plots, dot plots and back-to-back stem-and-leaf plots.
Interpret distributions of two sets of data using measures of center, measures of variability (interquartile range and range) and shape (clusters, peaks, gaps and symmetry).
Analyze two distributions of data to infer conclusions that are consistent with available data.
Calculate the probabilities of dependent and independent events.
Use probabilities of simple events to calculate the probabilities of independent and dependent events.
Use scatterplots to summarize bivariate data.
Classify type (positive, negative, no relation) of bivarate data correlation in scatterplots.
Represent trends in bivariate data, when appropriate, with a linear model.
Represent the linear model with a linear equation in slope-intercept form.
Predict the value of one variable based on the other using the linear model to fit the data.
Understand misuse and distortion of data, statistical measures and graphical displays.
Understand how to determine outliers using the formula.
Understand the effect of an outlier on the mean, median, inter-quartile range and range of a set of data.
Understand misuses of surveys, sampling, graphs and statistics.
Number and Operations
Use ratios and rates to solve problems.
Use proportions to solve problems.
Select appropriate units and explain the result based on the problem being solved.
Use properties of exponents to simplify expressions.
Represent numerical expressions with exponents in their simplest forms.
Represent algebraic expressions with exponents in their simplest forms.
Use strategies to compute square roots and cube roots of numbers that are not perfect squares or perfect cubes.
Algebra
Use appropriate properties and strategies to combine and factor algebraic expressions.
Execute all operations with algebraic expressions (division by monomials only).
Use associative, commutative and distributive properties to combine algebraic expressions.
Analyze quadratic expressions to determine their factors.
Use direct and indirect variation to solve problems.
Use substitution strategies to solve equations involving direct and inverse variation.
Use literal equations to represent direct and indirect variation.
Explain the effect that an increase or decrease in one variable will have on the other variables.
Analyze patterns of change in functional relationships.
Differentiate between linear, quadratic and exponential patterns of change.
Identify intervals of increase or decrease.
Explain the rate of increase or decrease on an interval.
Understand functions based on mathematical and real-world phenomena.
Categorize relations as functions or "not functions".
Use appropriate terminology and notation (function, domain, range and intercepts) associated with functions.
Interpret the relationship of constants and coefficients for data presented in graphs, tables and equations.
Represent linear functions in a variety of equivalent forms (including point-slope).
Use graphs, tables and symbols to solve linear equations.
Use tables and graphs to solve exponential equations.
Use graphs, tables, and properties to solve quadratic equations.
Use strategies to find solutions for linear and exponential relationships.
Represent linear and exponential relationships in the form of models.
Use strategies to solve systems of linear equations in two variables, graphically and symbolically.
Use tables and graphs to solve pairs of linear inequalities in two variables.
Use tables and graphs to solve systems with linear and exponential inequalities.
Geometry
Analyze properties of geometric shapes in the Cartesian coordinate system.
Use strategies to calculate the slope, distance between points, coordinates of the midpoints and the distance from a point to a line.
Use geometric properties to identify geometric shapes.
Use formulas to solve problems involving area and volume.
Recognize examples of chord, tangent and secant in visual displays.
Use formulas to solve problems involving the areas of polygons.

Understand the 3:1 relationship between volumes of right circular cylinders and cones with the same height and circular base and between the volume of a prism and pyramid with the same base area and height.
Use formulas to solve problems involving volume of right prisms, pyramids, circular cylinders and right circular cones.

Represent the relationship between the surface area of prisms, cylinders and pyramids to the sum of the area(s) of their base(s) and lateral surfaces using planar nets to illustrate and sum the relevant measures.
Statistics and Probability
Analyze statistical distributions in terms of the relationships among shape, center, spread and outliers.
Explain the effect of an outlier on the mean, median and range of various graphical displays.
Compare shape, center, and spread of univariate data using graphical displays, quartiles, percentiles, outliers, means and standard deviations.
Infer trends in bivariate data.
Use formal strategies for placement of lines of best fit to model bivariate data.
Infer trends in bivariate data displayed in scatter plots to determine informally if the data is best fit with a linear, exponential or quadratic model.
Discrete
Use vertex-edge graphs to route and optimize critical paths.
Apply the properties of vertex-edge graphs.
Use vertex-edge graphs and algorithmic thinking (a step-by-step plan) to model and solve problems involving efficient route, Euler Circuits, and Hamiltonian Circuits.
Number and Operations
Represent expressions involving rational exponents in various forms.
Translate numbers with rational exponents, limited to exponents in the form 1/n, into expressions with nth roots.
Represent algebraic expressions with exponents in their simplest forms.
Use arithmetic operations on matrices.
Represent numerical and relational data characterized with two or more variables using matrices.
Use addition, subtraction and scalar multiplication of matrices.
Use the properties of matrix multiplication and multiply matrices to solve problems in context.
Algebra
Represent functions as mathematical models of real-world phenomena.
Represent absolute value, step and piecewise linear functions, and quadratic functions using models.
Use graphs, symbols and tables to represent functions.
Use strategies to solve systems of equations and inequalities and interpret their solutions.
Use matrices to solve systems of linear equations, interpreting their solutions.
Use appropriate strategies to solve systems of combinations of equations or inequalities, interpreting their solutions.
Represent transformations of families of functions.
Represent transformations of absolute value, quadratic and exponential functions in a coordinate plane.
Illustrate translations, reflections and dilations.
Use arithmetic operations with rational expressions and to simplify rational expressions.
Use arithmetic operations to combine rational expressions.
Use arithmetic algorithms to simplify rational expressions.
Understand the relationship between functions and their inverses.
Use function notation to find the sum, difference, product and quotient of two or more functions.
Use tables, graphs and symbols to find the inverse of a function.
Explain how the composition of a function and its inverse returns the identity function, ƒ(ƒ<sup>-1</sup>(x)) = x
Illustrate the relationship between exponential and logarithmic functions.
Use properties of logarithms to simplify and solve problems.
Use properties to convert between exponential and logarithmic form for positive integer-base logarithms.
Use logarithmic properties to simplify logarithms.
Use appropriate properties and strategies to solve linear, quadratic, exponential, logarithmic and rational equations.
Use graphs, tables, factoring and the quadratic formula to solve quadratic equations with real number coefficients, interpreting the solutions.
Represent rational equations with linear and quadratic denominators, in their simplest forms, identifying restrictions.
Use graphs, tables and appropriate properties to solve rational equations with linear and quadratic denominators.
Use appropriate properties to solve exponential and logarithmic equations symbolically, numerically and graphically.
Analyze the characteristics of power, polynomial, rational, exponential, radical and periodic functions.
Determine the theoretical and practical domain and range.
Determine the zeros, extremes and intercepts.
Identify intervals for which the function is continuous and/or discontinuous, increasing and/or decreasing.
Determine end behavior.
Analyze connections among functions represented in numeric, symbolic, graphical and verbal forms.
Represent problems involving repeated motion with models and graphs.
Represent problems involving repeated motion as a function of time with models and graphs
Represent varying parameters of starting point, distance, rate and repetitions when modeling.
Represent periodic functions (sine and cosine) using the unit circle and angles from special triangles.
Interpret periodic functions (sine and cosine) with varying parameters (amplitude, vertical shift and period).
Analyze function transformations.
Compare different types of functions.
Determine horizontal and vertical shifts as well as the stretching and shrinking of a function in comparison to the parent function
Geometry
Infer geometric relationships within an axiomatic system.
Construct a simple logical truth table for conjunction, disjunction, negation and conditional relations.
Infer conclusions from given information.
Evaluate the validity of conclusions drawn from the validity of conditionals, converses, inverses, contrapositives and biconditionals.
Summarize the structure and relationships between undefined terms, defined terms, axioms/postulates, methods of reasoning and theorems.
Use paper-folding techniques, compasses and straight edges and dynamic geometric software to make connections among geometric relationships.
Generate conjectures in order to test and validate geometric relationships.
Generate conjectures which can be verified by informal arguments or reject by counterexample
Generate direct and indirect arguments and identify inconsistencies.
Explain the relationships among angles formed by perpendicular lines and transversals of parallel lines.
Use available information and geometric principles to prove similarity and congruence among triangles, noting that congruence is a special case of similarity.
Use the concepts of similarity and congruence to solve problems.
Use properties of similarity and congruency to determine or calculate the measures of corresponding parts of similar figures.
Identify the conditions that are sufficient to guarantee similarity of polygons with more than three sides.
Apply properties of similarity and congruency to other polygons.
Represent geometric transformations algebraically using matrices.
Use matrix operations to model translations, reflections, origin-centered dilations and origin-centered rotations (90°, 180°, and 270°).
Understand the relationship of rigidity to congruence and that of dilations to similarity.
Represent circles as equations and graphs in the coordinate plane.
Represent circles as equations based on the center and the radius, the center and a point on the circle and the endpoints of the diameter.
Construct arguments to prove geometric conjectures and theorems.

Construct arguments that prove conjectures and theorems or disprove conjectures related to:
  1. angle bisectors
  2. medians
  3. isosceles triangles
  4. perpendicular bisectors
  5. altitudes
  6. geometric mean
Construct arguments to prove the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse in multiple ways.
Construct arguments to prove properties of special quadrilaterals.
Use properties to determine measures within circles.
Calculate the measure of central angles, inscribed angles and circumscribed angles.
Calculate arc measure and arc length within a circle.
Use the Pythagorean Theorem, trigonometric ratios, properties of special right triangles and the concept of similarity, individually and in combination to solve problems.
Use the Pythagorean Theorem to solve problems in two- and three-dimensional settings.
Use sines, consines and tangents to determine side lengths and angle measures in right triangles.
Use properties of special right triangles to solve problems.
Analyze three-dimensional figures in terms of their volumes, surface areas and cross-sectional shapes.
Use formulas and strategies to solve problems involving volume and surface area of cones, spheres and composite figures.

Use the 3:2:1 relationship among volumes of circular cylinders, hemispheres and cones with the same height and circular base and 3:1 relationship between the volume of a prism and pyramid with the same base area and height.
Statistics and Probability
Use geometric models to solve probability problems.
Use the sizes of partitioned regions within regular geometric figures to solve probability problems.
Apply statistical concepts and principles to develop linear models.
Generate linear models using least-squares regression lines.
Evaluate the strength of relationship for bivariate numerical data both informally and by using the correlation coefficient.
Evaluate the fit and appropriateness of a linear model by calculating the Sum of the Squared Errors or the Mean Absolute Deviation from the least-squares regression lines.
Infer trends in bivariate data displayed in scatter plots, and best fit lines.
Apply probability concepts and principles to multistage probability experiments.
Analyze two-stage experiments in terms of sample spaces.
Use diagrams and the multiplication rule for probability to calculate probabilities.
Compare independent and dependent compound events in terms of their probabilities.
Discrete
Use weighted vertex-edge graphs, critical path analysis and weighted digraphs to solve problems dealing with optimization.
Use weighted vertex-edge graphs and minimum spanning trees to solve problems.
Use critical path analysis and weighted digraphs to optimally schedule large projects that are comprised of many smaller tasks.
Understand the role that linear programming plays in optimization.
Use linear functions to optimize situations that arise within a system with linear constraints on the variables. (linear programming)
Algebra
Use recursion to model and solve problems.
Calculate the sum of a finite sequence.
Calculate the sum of an infinite sequence.
Differentiate between the convergence or divergence of a given series.
Use iterative processes to write explicit definitions and formulas for arithmetic and geometric sequences.
Evaluate explicit definitions using inductive proofs.
Use matrices to model and solve problems.
Analyze data.
Use matrix expressions to solve problems.
Use graph theory to model relationships and solve problems.
Represent graphs using diagrams and matrices.
Translate between diagram and matrix representations of graphs.
Understand coloring of a graph, chromatic number of a graph and the Four Color Theorem.
Apply coloring algorithms in problems such as mapping and scheduling.
Use trees to represent problems involving decision making.
Statistics and Probability
Analyze data to solve problems.
Apply methods of data collection.
Apply statistical principles and methods in sample surveys.
Calculate measures of central tendency and spread.
Use the normal distribution curve.
Interpret graphical displays of data.
Compare distributions of data.
Use theoretical and experimental probability to model and solve problems.
Use addition and multiplication principles.
Calculate permutations and combinations.
Generate simulations for probability models.
Calculate expected values and determine fairness.
Use discrete random variables to solve problems.
Apply the Binomial Theorem.
Discrete
Evaluate decision making methods and strategies.
Apply properties of fair division.
Use majority, plurality, points-for-preference, runoff, pair-wise comparison, approval and apportionment to make fair decisions.
Analyze fair decision strategies in terms of fairness and Arrow's Theorem.
Apply mathematical concepts and strategies related to information processing, particularly on the internet with a focus on access, security, accuracy and efficiency.
Algebra
Use a diverse array of functions (logarithmic, piecewise-defined, power, trigonometric, recursively-defined and polynomial) to model and solve problems.
Evaluate the appropriate use of each function.
Explain the significance each function has with respect to the data or problem situation being modeled.
Use multiple representations to analyze trigonometric functions.
Use the unit circle to generate trigonometric functions.
Analyze transformations with respect to period, amplitude and vertical and horizontal shifts.
Apply the law of sines and the law of cosines to solve problems.
Statistics and Probability
Construct models (including calculator-generated models of linear, polynomial, exponential, trigonometric, power and logarithmic functions) of bivariate data to solve problems.
Interpret the constants, coefficients and bases in the context of the data.
Evaluate models for goodness-of-fit; use the most appropriate model to draw conclusions and make predictions.
Evaluate sets of data considering the source and the design of the study.
Identify when arguments based on data confuse correlation with causation.
Analyze univariate data to solve problems.
Apply methods of data collection.
Apply statistical principles and methods in sample surveys.
Use the normal distribution curve.
Interpret graphical displays of univariate data.
Compare distributions of univariate data.
Use theoretical and experimental probability to model and solve problems.
Use addition and multiplication principles.
Calculate permutations and combinations.
Generate simulations of probability models.
Calculate expected values and determine fairness.
Apply discrete random variables to solve problems.
Apply the Binomial Theorem.
Algebra
Analyze the characteristics of exponential (including e<sup>x</sup>), natural logarithmic and trigonometric functions.
Identify theoretical and practical domain and range.
Calculate the zeros, extrema, and intercepts.
Identify intervals for which the function is continuous and/or discontinuous, increasing and/or decreasing.
Describe end behavior and any asymptotic behavior.
Compare different types of functions.
Describe horizontal and vertical shifts as well as the stretching and shrinking of a function in comparison to the parent function.
Analyze connections among relationships represented in numeric/tabular, symbolic, graphical and verbal forms.
Use the limit of a function graphically, numerically and algebraically.
Evaluate the limit of a function (graphically and algebraically) as x approaches a certain value.
Evaluate the limit of a function, as x approaches infinity.
Identify behavior of a function associated with non-existence of a limit.
Use limits to identify continuity at a point.
Use functions (polynomial, power, rational, exponential, logarithmic, logistic, piecewise-defined functions and greatest integer) to solve problems.
Use graphs and algebraic properties to solve problems.
Understand the relationship between the exponential and logarithmic functions.
Use the laws of exponents to prove the basic properties of a natural logarithm.
Use properties and attributes of rational, exponential, logarithmic and trigonometric functions to solve problems.
Use calculator-generated models of linear, polynomial, exponential, trigonometric, power, logistic and logarithmic functions of bivariate data to solve problems.
Interpret the constants, coefficients and bases in the context of the data.
Use the most appropriate model to draw conclusions and make predictions.
Use composition and inverse of functions to solve problems.
Use algebraic properties to solve problems involving trigonometric and inverse trigonometric functions; justify results.
Generate trigonometric functions on the unit circle.
Analyze functions with respect to period, amplitude, and vertical and horizontal shifts, shrinks, and stretches.
Apply the law of sines and the law of cosines to solve problems.
Use Pythagorean, sum, difference, double angle and half-angle identities to find exact values and establish other identities.
Use graphs and algebraic properties to solve and interpret the constants and coefficients of polar equations.
Geometry
Use vectors in two dimensions to model and solve problems.
Represent vectors using addition, subtraction, and scalar multiplication.
Use both position and component representations of vectors to solve problems.
Use parametric equations to solve problems representing linear and non-linear motion.
Use complex numbers as vectors to solve problems.
Analyze three-dimensional figures.
Use cross-sectional shapes of slices of three-dimensional objects to solve problems.

Analyze the behavior of recursively-defined functions.
Calculate the sum of a finite sequence.
Calculate the sum of an infinite sequence.
Differentiate between the convergence or divergence of a given series.
Translate between recursive and explicit representations.
Differentiate between probabilities of dependent and independent events.
Evaluate whether events are mutually exclusive and compute the probability of the given event.
Explain how to compute the probability of an event not occurring.
Use permutations and combinations to determine the number of ways events can occur and compute the probability of the event occurring.

Use the Binomial Theorem to expand powers of binomials.
